snippet.textDisplay: I am literally just as frustrated and annoyed as Dr. Mike is. I work in an outpatient office with multiple specialities, along with Internal Medicine, and it is so frustrating to have panicking patients on the phone. It is taking a heavy toll on us healthcare workers when there are patients really needing to get in contact with their provider for their diabetes or heart medications, for example. PANICKING WILL NOT SOLVE THIS PANDEMIC! I reside in Dallas, Texas and back in October we were hit with a tornado which was on ground for about 30 minutes and we were lucky enough that there were no deaths across the city (feeling very happy and blessed to report to people who don't know about this). With the proper protocol of knowing what to do in an event like this, we did not panic! I gathered my family, and my kitten, and got shelter in the safest part of our townhome with obviously some anxiety/fear but we stayed calm. My point is…if you follow the recommended CDC guidelines and do your part on taking care of yourself and your surroundings, chaos and shortage of supplies in stores will lower. It only takes one person at a second to make this pandemic be less fearful and act accordingly.

snippet.textDisplay:
The South Korea .60% statistic NO LONGER VALID. Many of us who have been tracking the data have stated that we will really get a good feel for the dynamics of Covid-19 once the South Korea data comes out (given some concerns about the validity of the China data for several reasons).  Along those lines on March 05, 2020 Business Insider made the claim that the South Korean situation shows us that the Covid-19 has a CFR of only around .6%.  When I heard the data I felt the optimism might be premature and unfounded.  So I decided to track the numbers.  Here are the raw data points and the CFR (case fatality rate) from the time of that article to today.




3/5 Total cases = 6593 Total deaths = 42 43/6593  = .00682  = CFR 0.682%*

3/6 Total cases = 7041 Total deaths = 43 42/7041  = .00611  = CFR 0.611%

3/7 Total cases = 7134 Total deaths = 48 48/7134  = .00672  = CFR 0.672%

3/8 Total cases = 7313 Total deaths = 50 50/7313  = .00684  = CFR 0.684%

3/9 Total cases = 7478 Total deaths = 53 53/7478  = .00709  = CFR 0.709%

3/10 Total cases = 7513 Total deaths = 60 60/7513  = .00799  = CFR 0.799%

3/11 Total cases = 7755 Total deaths = 60 60/7755  = .00774  = CFR 0.774%

3/12 Total cases = 7869 Total deaths = 66 66/7869  = .00839  = CFR 0.839%

3/13 Total cases = 7979 Total deaths = 67 67/7979  = .00840  = CFR 0.840%

3/14 Total cases = 8086 Total deaths = 72 72/8086  = .00902  = CFR 0.902%

*BI obviously took a look at the prior day’s data or data from earlier in the day 




Observations (factual):

1. There has been an obvious upward trend in the CFR in SK over the past week.

2. It would be logical to assume this general trend will continue until it reaches a point of “diminishing returns” (i.e., until it reaches the final, truer CFR number)

3. The amount of testing done actually does determine the (perceived) CFR.  When little testing is done the CFR is disproportionately high at first and then recedes to a more accurate number.  When a lot of testing is done (as in SK) the CFR will be initially low but will rise in time to the more accurate number. 




Observations (opinions):

1. The numbers that came out of China are not worth taking seriously.

2. The numbers out of SK are our first and best data points to understand what we are dealing with.

3. SK’s and America’s final CFR will NOT be the same (as we look back years from now).  Their early testing, quick responses and disciplined populace will make their national CFR one of the lowest once the dust settles.  Iran will be on the opposite end.  America, in my opinion will...




Please respond to this if you’d like to get an update on the data in a week or so.  Just say “Yes” or “Interesting” or whatever.  In a week I’ll run the numbers and re-comment on this very same thread and that should send an update to your email box.




For the BI article see here:  https://www.businessinsider.com/south-korea-coronavirus-testing-death-rate-2020-3

For the MedCram video that referenced this (and the comments/observations I was making then) see here:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Eeh054-Hx1U&t=3s

snippet.textDisplay: One thing you did not address, which I want to add: Some people state that quarantining the sick or suspected-to-be-sick people is useless, as the virus is so infectious that most of us will get in contact with it sooner or later anyway. While quarantining may not necessarily stop the virus from spreading, it at least drastically reduces it's momentum, granting more time for counter-measures.

snippet.textDisplay: It's so hard to get tested. I work in the US in a hospital. I don't directly take care of patients but we walk through the same hallways, entrances, lobby, and employees share the same cafeteria with visitors. And we know that people can get sick from breathing the same air. I started coughing and feeling really tired so I inquired about getting tested for Corona virus, the critieria is that I have to have had proof of direct contact with confirmed cases to qualify for testing. I would never find out the names of confirmed patients who came through the same lobby and shared the same cafeteria, so I would never be qualified to test even if I was exposed. That explains the low numbers positive, the testing critieria is very strict and will miss many.
